Death in Paradise: Kris Marshall quits BBC show as Ardal O’Hanlon takes over lead role 
The tropical murder mystery show is set to have a new main character Thursday 2 February 2017 09:52 BST Click to followES Entertainment Leaving: Kris Marshall is quitting BBC detective show Death in Paradise BBC/Red Planet Pictures/Denis Guyenon 
The BBC ’s tropical murder mystery show Death in Paradise is set for a shake-up in its next series, as lead actor Kris Marshall has announced he is leaving the show. 
The actor, also known for his role in BBC sitcom My Family, has starred in four series of Death in Paradise, taking over from original star Ben Miller. 
“Death in Paradise has been an incredible experience, six months every year filming on a tropical island in the sunshine – what’s not to love,” Marshall said. 
“Humphrey was socially awkward and clumsy but also brilliant, I’ll miss him but it’s time to hand over to someone new and spend more time with my family.” The biggest and best TV shows of 2017 The biggest and best TV shows of 2017 1/4 Sherlock, Series 4

The show has already bagged a new lead in the form of My Hero star Ardal O’Hanlon – who made his debut appearance in the most recent episode of the comedy-drama as DI Jack Mooney. David Tennant promises Broadchurch ending 'strikes the perfect note' 
“I am delighted to be joining Death in Paradise and exploring what’s made Mooney up and leave London for a life in the Caribbean,” he said. “I’ve already had a taste of filming in Guadeloupe and can’t wait to get back.” 
Marshall’s final episode will be aired next week on Thursday, February 9 – and it’s currently unknown whether his character will be killed off. Top five contenders for the next Doctor Who
